fields.label: Wonder
fields.title: We’re in this together

content.value: Teaching tomorrow’s scientists and researchers to ask the big questions

fields.title: Wonder Chapter header
fields.description: A graphic illustration collage of a young woman, a sun, a map of the stars in the sky, and two students building a project together

fields.title: Wonder thumbnail alt
fields.description: A graphic illustration collage of: a young woman looking to her left, a round yellow celestial body, and a map of the stars

fields.creditJumpText: As humans, we can’t help but ask why and what.

content.value: Every long-distance relationship, especially one that stretches across 93 million miles, has its difficult moments.

fields.title: LASP 1 background video preload
fields.description: The clouds and stars move across the nighttime sky above the Rocky Mountains.

content.value: Take the celestial courtship between the sun and the Earth.

Sure, the sun warms the Earth, stirs our atmosphere, influences our weather, propels our orbit and gives us humans life. But the sun—its vibrations heard here in sound captured by NASA—can also be an unpredictable tempest, an insanely hot dynamo that pumps out 4 million tons of matter into energy every second.

fields.title: LASP-3
fields.description: Viewpoint from space looking down on planet Earth.

content.value: Energy from a monster solar storm, for example, hit Earth in 1859, causing widespread powerful auroras in the sky and havoc on the ground with telegraph systems, the modern telecommunications of the time.

While the intensity and frequency of solar flares vary, a storm of this magnitude today would cause widespread disruption to electrical grids, global positioning systems, air travel and even the internal compasses of racing pigeons and wedding doves.

fields.title: LASP4-Vert
fields.description: A scientific viewpoint of a solar flare showing red and orange colors.

content.value: Understanding the impact of solar events on us Earthlings is important for scientific, social and economic reasons.
Scientists know solar events like this can happen but don’t always know why or when.

fields.title: LASP5-Vert
fields.description: A scientific image of a solar flare showing green and yellow colors

fields.label: LASP 6
fields.title: LASP 6
fields.bodyAudioText: “I think we study the sun—as humans, as scientists—for the same reason we study anything, and it's that we don't know everything about it yet. It's human nature to want to know, and so, that's why we do it.”

fields.title: LASP6- Full
fields.description: A young woman with long wavy red hair listens intently to a female college student explain her research in a crowded room. They are at an expo where college students share posters about the research they worked on all summer.

fields.title: M-Wonder-6
fields.description: A young woman with long wavy red hair listens intently to a female college student explain her research in a crowded room. They are at an expo where college students share posters about the research they worked on all summer.

content.value: Willow Reed, a 2017 graduate of CU Boulder, is part of the next generation of scientists who learn alongside talented CU researchers supported by generous donors.

Her research of solar flares builds from a childhood passion for space science, one that was launched because of CU Boulder’s location amid one of the greatest concentrations of solar physics institutes in the world.
It’s this collaboration that allows places like CU to nurture passion and curiosity across disciplines and perspectives, encouraging bright minds to ask big questions:
How do we cure cancer?
Will artificial intelligence change us?
What’s beyond our solar system?

fields.label: LASP 9
fields.title: LASP 9
fields.bodyAudioText: “Science is important because we as humans can't help but ask the question why or what, and we want to know more, and if we don't know all the answers, we're going to keep searching for them. But you have to have public support, so getting people involved in science is what's shaping our next steps as society and as humanity."

fields.title: LASP-9
fields.description: Willow Reed looks to the side as her long red wavy hair falls in front of her jean jacket. On the wall behind her is a large black and white artwork of the moon.

fields.title: M-Wonder-9
fields.description: Willow Reed looks to the side as her long red wavy hair falls in front of her jean jacket. On the wall behind her is a large black and white artwork of the moon.

fields.label: LASP 10
fields.title: LASP 10
fields.bodyAudioText: "Not even looking at astronomy or astrophysics, look at general science. If you don't have public support, you don't have funding. Then how else are you supposed to discover the Titanic, or shoot things into space, or counteract climate change? It's a big deal.”

fields.title: LASP-10
fields.description: Willow Reed smiles and looks directly at you, a large black and white artwork of the moon is behind her on the wall.

fields.title: M-Wonder-10
fields.description: Willow Reed smiles and looks directly at you, a large black and white artwork of the moon is behind her on the wall.

content.value: Last summer, Reed served as program director of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) for the Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics (LASP), the same one she participated as an undergraduate student at CU Boulder.

fields.title: LASP-11
fields.description: A young woman with long redy wavy hair stands with her hands on her hips and smiles amind the group of college students working on experiments outside. The young woman is wearing a black Star Wars T-shirt and eyeglasses.

content.value: Funded by the National Science Foundation, REUs support hands-on research opportunities for undergraduate students and are offered at academic institutions across the country.

fields.title: LASP12 - Full
fields.description: Clusters of college students stand outside on the CU Boulder East campus working together to build different projects. One group is working on a tube that will funnel sunlight. In the forefront a female student with a large leg tattoo checks her phone.

fields.title: M-Wonder-12
fields.description: Clusters of college students stand outside on the CU Boulder East campus working together to build different projects. One group is working on a tube that will funnel sunlight. In the forefront a female student with a large leg tattoo checks her phone.

content.value: Twenty-seven undergraduates from around the country attended the REU led by Reed. Opportunities like this are possible because of the incredible partnerships CU forms with scientific laboratories and research institutions here in Colorado and around the world.

fields.title: LASP-13
fields.description: A female college student examines in her hands a solar-powered machine she and her classmates built. On the front of the contraption, which has gears and a mirror, is taped a printout of a cat wearing a sunflower costume. The flatirons are in the background.

fields.title: M-Wonder-13
fields.description: A female college student examines in her hands a solar-powered machine she and her classmates built. On the front of the contraption, which has gears and a mirror, is taped a printout of a cat wearing a sunflower costume. The flatirons are in the background.

content.value: They learned technical skills like software programming and building sensors.

fields.title: LASP14 - Full
fields.description: A female student's smile is reflected in the mirror of a solar powered camera built from wires and particle board by her and her classmates. On the machine is taped a printout of a cat wearing a sunflower costume.

fields.title: M-Wonder-14
fields.description: A female student's smile is reflected in the mirror of a solar powered camera built from wires and particle board by her and her classmates. On the machine is taped a printout of a cat wearing a sunflower costume.

content.value: They learned how to conduct proper academic research.

fields.title: LASP15-Full
fields.description: A male college student kneels to get a better look at a solar-powered camera his female classmate is leaning over. She is trying to attach wires and other materials to make it function. They are inside a classroom where other students are also trying to build similar projects.

fields.title: M-Wonder-15
fields.description: A male college student kneels to get a better look at a solar-powered camera his female classmate is leaning over. She is trying to attach wires and other materials to make it function. They are inside a classroom where other students are also trying to build similar projects.

content.value: They discovered what they want to research.

fields.title: LASP16-Full
fields.description: An aerial shot of students standing in front of their posters at the expo. One female points to her poster as two males listen.

fields.title: M-Wonder-16
fields.description: An aerial shot of students standing in front of their posters at the expo. One female points to her poster as two males listen.

content.value: And they met other researchers and scientists.

fields.title: LASP17- Full
fields.description: College students sit on blankets on the ground as dusk settles in along the flatirons. They are on a field trip, taking notes by lantern and lamp about the night sky.

fields.title: M-Wonder-17
fields.description: College students sit on blankets on the ground as dusk settles in along the flatirons. They are on a field trip, taking notes by lantern and lamp about the night sky.

content.value: Hazel Bain was an REU mentor this year. A research scientist with the Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences at CU Boulder and a contract employee with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Bain has mentored students through other programs, including an REU at UC Berkeley.
As an undergraduate student, Bain was mentored.

fields.label: LASP 19
fields.title: LASP 19
fields.bodyAudioText: “The times that I’ve thrived in my career is when I’ve had a mentor that advised me and supported me and cheered me on. You can learn the physics from a book, but you can’t learn the job from a book, so it’s a good way to figure out how to navigate this career.”

fields.title: LASP19-Vert
fields.description: A female scientist stands with her hands on her hips in front of a wall showing red and yellow images about solar flares.

content.value: Thania Ruiz, an aerospace engineering student at CU Boulder, said the research experience gave her the confidence to claim her spot in the scientific field.

fields.label: LASP 21
fields.title: LASP 21
fields.bodyAudioText: “Sometimes in my major, there's a bunch of guys all the time and there's hardly any girls...That's when I meet people that are also different, they're going through the same experiences as I am, it helps them feel like, 'Oh, you know what? Maybe I am in the right track. Maybe I am where I'm supposed to be.'"

fields.title: LASP21-Vert
fields.description: A female CU student with long dark hair and a blue shirt explains her research poster at an expo on the CU Boulder East Campus.

content.value: Reed knows that feeling. As a freshman, she wanted to do research but hadn’t chosen a field yet, so her advisor invited her to tag along in the REU. Most REU students were upperclassmen. She was the youngest in the room.

fields.title: LASP-22
fields.description: A large group of space science students stand on East Campus of CU Boulder with the majestic Flatirons behind them.

fields.title: M-Wonder-22
fields.description: A large group of space science students stand on East Campus of CU Boulder with the majestic Flatirons behind them.

fields.label: LASP 23
fields.title: LASP 23
fields.bodyAudioText: “Being a scientist is a huge part of my identity, but I'm not sure if it always was. On some level I think it was; I was always very curious as a child. I loved the science fair and doing that with my dad, but I also was a huge dancer and performer. That was also a large part of my identity back then; I would say it was bigger than being a scientist. Partly just because I didn't know what being a scientist was yet.”

fields.title: LASP23-Vert
fields.description: A young redheaded girl in kindergarten stands in front of her science fair poster about the solar system.

content.value: In her junior year, Reed received the Charles A. Barth Scholarship in Space Research.

fields.title: LASP24-Vert
fields.description: Willow Reed as an undergraduate student at CU stands in front of a large telescope. She is smiling and wearing a white CU Boulder sweatshirt.

content.value: Barth was a leader at LASP for nearly four decades and left a legacy of inspiring space science students.

fields.title: LASP25 - Full
fields.description: An old historic photo of a male scientist sitting in front of a desk with large vintage computers.

fields.title: M-Wonder-25
fields.description: An old historic photo of a male scientist sitting in front of a desk with large vintage computers.

content.value: Initially called the Upper Air Laboratory, LASP was created in 1948 by CU Boulder physicists (a decade before NASA was founded) to study Earth's atmosphere and develop instruments launched aboard rockets.

fields.title: LASP26-Full
fields.description: An old historic photo where three male scientists, one with a pocket protector, one with a bowtie and one with a skinny tie, stand around holding an early rocket.

fields.title: M-Wonder-26
fields.description: An old historic photo where three male scientists, one with a pocket protector, one with a bowtie and one with a skinny tie, stand around holding an early rocket.

content.value: The endowed scholarship was more than just financial relief for Reed. It was a chance to share her research with others in her field. She’s been investigating the sun ever since.

fields.title: LASP27--Vert
fields.description: A young woman stands in her graduation regalia in front of a building that is named Duane Physical Laboratories on the CU Boulder campus.

content.value: And she wants to share her work beyond the science community. Reed, who started her PhD at Montana State University this fall, has a personal mission to help the public gain a deeper understanding of science and all its applications.
As part of her career, Reed is hoping to expand science education and outreach in our communities.

fields.title: LASP28-Vert
fields.description: Willow Reed leans in intently to hear a female college student explain her research poster at an expo.

content.value: After all, as human beings, we love those “Eureka!” moments.

fields.title: LASP-29
fields.description: Willow Reed exclaims excitedly with her mouth open in the middle of a crowded student research expo while listening to a female college student explain her work.

fields.title: M-Wonder-29
fields.description: Willow Reed exclaims excitedly with her mouth open in the middle of a crowded student research expo while listening to a female college student explain her work.

fields.label: LASP 30
fields.title: LASP 30
fields.bodyAudioText: “You really need to get people excited, and not just on an elementary and middle school level, but on an adult level. If you can get adults excited, then they'll help support it. They'll help elect people that will fund it.”

fields.title: LASP-30
fields.description: Willow Reed smiles and looks off to the side, her red wavy hair hanging over her jean jacket. She is standing in the middle of an expo where students share posters about their scientific research.

fields.title: M-Wonder-30
fields.description: Willow Reed smiles and looks off to the side, her red wavy hair hanging over her jean jacket. She is standing in the middle of an expo where students share posters about their scientific research.

fields.label: LASP 31
fields.title: LASP 31
fields.bodyAudioText: “They will make sure that science moves forward so that everybody on the planet can learn and discover. That's why public outreach is important because we need people to appreciate science and want to fund it in order to continue doing it and discovering and solving these mysteries.”

fields.title: LASP-31
fields.description: A female astrophysicist looks to the side, her long wavy red hair falling in front of her jean jacket at a student research expo

fields.title: M-Wonder-31
fields.description: A female astrophysicist looks to the side, her long wavy red hair falling in front of her jean jacket at a student research expo

fields.socialMediaSuggestedDescription: What do homing pigeons, GPS and electrical grids have in common? Solar flares! Read about CU alumna Willow Reed, an astrophysicist studying these celestial storms to help keep us safe on Earth.

fields.label: Innovation
fields.title: We’re in this together

content.value: Building ability and access through technology

fields.title: Innovation CH
fields.description: A graphic illustration collage of a female faculty member smiling, a hand holding a mobile device, the Denver city skyline, a trio of college students collaborating around an iPad, and a man riding on the back of a wheelchair driven by a young girl

fields.title: Innovation thumbnail
fields.description: A graphic illustration collage of the pattern of a QR code in the background with a man riding on the back of a wheelchair driven by a young girl

fields.creditJumpText: Technology makes life possible for all of us.

content.value: Jade’s bare feet dangle around her mother’s waist and her head rolls forward like a sleepy child’s.

fields.title: Innovation-2
fields.description: A mother carries her barefoot daughter across a parking lot. The young girl rests her head on her mother's shoulder and clutches her stuffed animal - a faded pink bunny wearing a bright pink cape - as they enter the clinic.

fields.title: M-Innovation-2
fields.description: A mother carries her barefoot daughter across a parking lot. The young girl rests her head on her mother's shoulder and clutches her stuffed animal - a faded pink bunny wearing a bright pink cape - as they enter the clinic.

content.value: But her giggle gives her away: Jade is very much awake and excited. Today, she is at Assistive Technology Partners at CU Denver learning how to drive a motorized wheelchair.

fields.title: Innovation-3
fields.description: A young girl laughs after she kisses the hand of her occupational therapist.

fields.title: M-Innovation-3
fields.description: A young girl laughs after she kisses the hand of her occupational therapist.

fields.label: Innovation 4
fields.title: Innovation 4
fields.bodyAudioText:
"I am Brenda Ruiz, and my daughter Jade is 5 years old. And we are here for our appointment to get a power wheelchair.

Her personality is incredible. She is extremely independent. She has an infectious laugh. She loves Disney princesses. She loves playing with other kids her age. She loves being outdoors, and she is overall just a really happy kid."

fields.title: Innovation-4
fields.description: A young girl sits in an oversized stroller and smiles over her shoulder. The occupational therapist shows her a paper printout of the two princesses from the movie "Frozen."

fields.title: M-Innovation-4
fields.description: A young girl sits in an oversized stroller and smiles over her shoulder. The occupational therapist shows her a paper printout of the two princesses from the movie "Frozen."

content.value: When she was 3, Jade experienced a sudden loss of motor skills and muscle function. She was diagnosed with Krabbe’s Leukodystrophy, a rare genetic condition that affects her nervous system. She has been getting around in a stroller and manual wheelchair ever since.
But Jade was starting kindergarten this fall. It was time to put her in the driver’s seat.

fields.title: Innovation-5
fields.description: A mother caresses her young daughter's hair while they waits for the appointment to begin.

fields.label: Innovation 6
fields.title: Innovation 6
fields.bodyAudioText: "Jade having a motorized wheelchair will change the game essentially when it comes to school. She has overall lost so many of her abilities in such a short amount of time. And so having that motorized wheelchair gives back her independence and her control over her surroundings. I know that's very important for Jade."

fields.title: Innovation-6
fields.description: Outside in a parking lot, a mother straps her young daughter into a motorized wheelchair as a clinic staff member makes adjustments.

fields.label: Innovation 7
fields.title: Innovation 7
fields.bodyAudioText: "She's only 5, but she is very aware of her loss of control, and so this will be just a huge thing for her moving forward and growing and being able just...at school to keep up with other kids her age. I think that's going to be really important."

fields.title: Innovation-7
fields.description: A young girl laughs and looks at her hand around the joystick as she sits in a motorized wheelchair for the first time.

fields.title: M-Innovation-7
fields.description: A young girl laughs and looks at her hand around the joystick as she sits in a motorized wheelchair for the first time.

content.value: Jade’s co-pilots for the day are a well-loved pink rabbit with a cape and knickers she calls Super Bunny, and Brian Burne, an occupational therapist and assistive technology specialist at CU Denver.

fields.title: Innovation-8
fields.description: A male occupational therapist takes the hand of a young girl and helps her grab the joystick of a motorized wheelchair. A stuffed pink bunny sits on her lap.

fields.title: M-Innovation-8
fields.description: A male occupational therapist takes the hand of a young girl and helps her grab the joystick of a motorized wheelchair. A stuffed pink bunny sits on her lap.

content.value: Once strapped in, Jade’s hand wraps around the joystick of the motorized wheelchair.

fields.title: Innovation-9
fields.description: In a parking lot outside the clinic, a young girl gleefully laughs as she moves the motorized wheelchair forward for the first time. A male occupational therapist looks on.

fields.title: M-Innovation-9
fields.description: In a parking lot outside the clinic, a young girl gleefully laughs as she moves the motorized wheelchair forward for the first time. A male occupational therapist looks on.

fields.title: Innovation- 10-Bubble wrap still
fields.description: 5-year-old Jade Ruiz practices driving a motorized wheelchair over bubble wrap in the parking lot outside Assistive Technology Partners at CU Denver.

fields.label: Innovation 11
fields.title: Innovation 11
fields.bodyAudioText: "The University of Colorado, having this program in place, is incredible. It’s just been amazing to bring Jade here and work with these phenomenal staff members here, and they are so good to us…it’s just such a benefit to our family."

fields.title: Innovation-11
fields.description: A young girl's handgrabs green berries off a bush near the edge of a parking lot. A stuffed pink bunny sits in her lap.

content.value: A disability can happen to someone due to birth, injury, disease or aging.
In fact, one in four adults—61 million in the United States alone—have a disability that impacts major life activities, according to a report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
"At some point in their lives, most people will either have a disability or know someone who has a one," says Cathy Bodine, who first joined Assistive Technology Partners in 1996.
Bodine, who serves as executive director and an associate professor of bioengineering at CU Denver, is internationally recognized for her work in assistive technology.

fields.title: Innovation-13
fields.description: A female faculty member stands in front of a "Bioengineering" sign in a hallway on the CU Denver campus.

fields.title: M-Innovation-13
fields.description: A female faculty member stands in front of a "Bioengineering" sign in a hallway on the CU Denver campus.

fields.label: Innovation 14
fields.title: Innovation 14

content.value: Her take on the world is that people, with and without disabilities, all want the same basic things.
Bodine is inspired by the quote: "For people without disabilities, technology makes things easier. For people with disabilities, technology makes things possible."

fields.title: Innovation-14
fields.description: A female faculty member smiles in front of a blue wall

fields.title: M-Innovation-14
fields.description: A female faculty member smiles in front of a blue wall

content.value: Assistive Technology Partners uses innovative technology and engineering to help those living with disabilities, including sensory, cognitive, mobility and communication needs, access the world around them.
The program has thrived, thanks to a philanthropic partnership ATP has with Colorado’s construction industry.

For more than a decade, a group led by CU alumnus Bill Caile and his wife, Sara, has supported ATP through an annual event called Déjà Vu Rendezvous, attracting a kind of “who’s who” in the Colorado construction industry.

With both financial and in-kind contributions from this generous group—as well as support from both CU Denver's College of Engineering, Design and Computing and the dual-campus Department of Bioengineering shared between CU Denver and CU Anschutz—Assistive Technology Partners moved into a renovated space on campus in 2016.

Since 2008, efforts by Caile and his industry partners have raised over $2 million for Assistive Technology Partners, including funding for an endowed professorship, clinical support, a bioengineering endowment and a scholarship program.

Endowed professorships are crucial to improving CU’s intellectual might. Innovative academic leaders attract the best and brightest students and create opportunities for brilliant ideas to launch, grow and flourish.
It's paying off: Starting in late 2019, ATP will be designated as the Center for Inclusive Design and Engineering.
David Pak, left, was among a group of graduate students who received fellowships this year to research ways technology can help those living with cognitive disabilities.

Since 2001, the Coleman Institute for Cognitive Disabilities has sustained fellowships for graduate students across CU’s four campuses, thanks to a private endowment and annual contributions by donors.

fields.title: Innovation-18
fields.description: Two CU students, one male and one female, discuss their test using a mobile device.

fields.title: M-Innovation-18
fields.description: Two CU students, one male and one female, discuss their test using a mobile device.

fields.label: Innovation 19
fields.title: Innovation 19
fields.bodyAudioText: "I believe that the population is widely underserved, and it's even more kind of eye-opening... to just hear and see different stories of people with physical disabilities or cognitive disabilities overcoming all these challenges."

fields.title: Innovation-19
fields.description: Three male CU students cluster around a laptop at the front of a classroom, where a mock warehouse has been set up with shelves lined with cans and boxes of food. QR codes line the floor.

fields.title: M-Innovation-19
fields.description: Three male CU students cluster around a laptop at the front of a classroom, where a mock warehouse has been set up with shelves lined with cans and boxes of food. QR codes line the floor.

content.value: Led by Bodine, the students worked with clients with mild to moderate traumatic brain injuries, or TBIs. Clients were asked to shop for specific grocery items or stock shelves inside a mock warehouse on the CU Anschutz Medical Campus.

fields.title: Innovation- 20 Warehouse-still
fields.description: Canned goods line shelves in a mock warehouse at CU Anschutz.

content.value: The students tested which method was more helpful to the clients:

fields.title: Innovation-21
fields.description: A female college student watches on a computer screen live video of a client walking through the mock warehouse to monitor his movements.

fields.title: M-Innovation-21
fields.description: A female college student watches on a computer screen live video of a client walking through the mock warehouse to monitor his movements.

content.value: A traditional pen and paper shopping list …

fields.title: Innovation-22
fields.description: A young man walks holds a clipboard and looks at a shopping list while pushing a cart in a mock warehouse. The shelves are lined with cans and boxes of food.

fields.title: M-Innovation-22
fields.description: A young man walks holds a clipboard and looks at a shopping list while pushing a cart in a mock warehouse. The shelves are lined with cans and boxes of food.

content.value: …or a mobile device that can read black and white QR codes on the floor.

Using software, the mobile device serves as a digital, real-time job coach. The client uses the mobile device to scan QR codes. The mobile device shows the client photos of the desired items and their location in the warehouse should they ever need help.

fields.title: Innovation-23
fields.description: A hand holds a smart phone showing a bottle of soda. The phone's software confirms for the young man that the soda bottle he is looking for is in front of him on the shelf.

fields.title: M-Innovation-23
fields.description: A hand holds a smart phone showing a bottle of soda. The phone's software confirms for the young man that the soda bottle he is looking for is in front of him on the shelf.

content.value: Since its founding, Assistive Technology Partners has provided assistive technology information and services to more than 3 million people around the world.
The goal of ATP is to help people feel more confident and independent in all parts of their life through technology.

fields.title: Innovation-24
fields.description: A woman wears an long skinny instrument with a soft tip to push the keyboard buttons on her smart tablet to compose an email.

fields.title: M-Innovation-24
fields.description: A woman wears an long skinny instrument with a soft tip to push the keyboard buttons on her smart tablet to compose an email.

content.value: Technology can be something that helps you move.

fields.title: Innovation-26
fields.description: Designed by a student, a test wheelchair sits idle on a solar charging pad.

fields.title: M-Innovation-25
fields.description: Designed by a student, a test wheelchair sits idle on a solar charging pad.

content.value: Technology can be something that helps you think.

fields.title: Innovation-25
fields.description: A student project of blue and orange electrodes, plastic framing and wires

fields.title: M-Innovation-26
fields.description: A student project of blue and orange electrodes, plastic framing and wires

fields.label: Innovation 27
fields.title: Innovation 27
fields.bodyAudioText: "To me, it's all about the human who needs or wants to accomplish a task, but they need to mediate that through the use of technology because they can't do it for whatever reason on their own. To me, it augments human behavior or human activity."

fields.title: Innovation-27
fields.description: A clinic coordinator and woman in a wheelchair both flex their forearms triumphantly and smile.

fields.title: M-Innovation-27
fields.description: A clinic coordinator and young woman in a wheelchair both flex their forearms triumphantly and smile.

content.value: Technology helps Tammy Burton, a business owner and mother of two, get the perfect fit for her wheelchair, which will help her avoid unnecessary medical costs and relieve pain.

fields.title: Innovation-29
fields.description: A pair of hands holds a smart tablet to take a digital screening for measurements of foam padding on the seat of a motorized wheelchair

fields.title: M-Innovation-28
fields.description: A pair of hands holds a smart tablet to take a digital screening for measurements of foam padding on the seat of a motorized wheelchair

fields.label: Innovation 29
fields.title: Innovation 29
fields.bodyAudioText: "I really appreciate the independence that they can offer me. My life is very full and I need my wheels."

fields.title: Innovation-28
fields.description: A woman with bright blue hair and wearing glasses throws her head back to laugh as she sits in her wheelchair in the clinic.

fields.title: M-Innovation-29
fields.description: A woman with brown hair with a blue streak and wearing a bright pink tank top throws her head back and laughs.

content.value: Technology helps CU Denver alumna Kalyn Heffernan choose a new wheelchair, so she can safely move about the city she loves.

fields.title: Innovation-30
fields.description: A young woman sits in her motorized wheelchair and works on a laptop as two CU staff members look on and smile. They discuss how to improve her wheelchair.

fields.title: M-Innovation-30
fields.description: A young woman sits in her motorized wheelchair and works on a laptop as two CU staff members look on and smile. They discuss how to improve her wheelchair.

fields.label: Innovation 31
fields.title: Innovation 31
fields.bodyAudioText:
"I'm a musician, an activist and an educator, and I'm all over the city. I do a lot.
Everything that we do with disabilities is twice as hard and not typically built for us, so these kinds of places are super important. And having a team that's there to advocate on your behalf, but mostly let you advocate for yourself."

fields.title: Innovation-31
fields.description: A female's hand wearing rings on three fingers, touches the cracked screen on the joystick of her motorized wheelchair.

fields.title: M-Innovation-31
fields.description: A female's hand wearing rings on three fingers, touches the cracked screen on the joystick of her motorized wheelchair.

content.value: Technology helps make a great day of kindergarten for Jade and Super Bunny.

fields.title: Innovation-32
fields.description: A young girl holds up to show off her beloved stuffed toy, a faded pink bunny, and smiles.

fields.title: M-Innovation-32
fields.description: A young girl holds up to show off her beloved stuffed toy, a faded pink bunny, and smiles.

fields.socialMediaSuggestedDescription: When a rare genetic condition robbed 5-year-old Jade of her physical abilities, her family turned to CU. CU attracts the brightest faculty, staff and students who develop technology so people like Jade can thrive.

fields.label: Community
fields.title: We’re in this together

content.value: Keeping our communities healthy

fields.title: Community CH
fields.description: A graphic illustration collage of a physician, a stethoscope, a tall building from the CU Anschutz Medical Campus, and a street outreach group

fields.title: Community thumbnail alt
fields.description: A graphic illustration college showing: group of CU researchers and community organizers stand smiling in front of a street outreach van, a green and white street sign that says "E. Colfax" and a city map as a background

fields.creditJumpText: We all gain when our communities are healthy.

content.value: In Aurora, Colorado, there’s a 4-mile-long, 8-block stretch of East Colfax Avenue where the neighborhood housing is as diverse as its residents.

Century-old farmhouses, postwar brick cottages and dense midcentury apartment complexes share space with few trees and many parking lots. Its families hail from more than 130 countries, according to the local school district.

With its proximity to pollutants from major roads and industrial sites—coupled with indoor environmental factors like dust, mold, mildew, smoke and pet dander—the “Colfax Corridor,” as researchers call it, is a prime location to study a public health threat like asthma.

fields.title: Community -2-Colfax Drive still
fields.description: Driving down Colfax Avenue past other vehicles and shops in Aurora, Colorado.

content.value: How to tackle that threat started, as some big ideas do, with a chance conversation.
About the Aurora residents who live just down the street from the CU Anschutz Medical Campus and who struggle to make ends meet.
About the community leaders concerned about the well-being of these neighbors who lack access to safe, stable and healthy housing.
About the need for research data that could help make a difference not only in the health of these households, but in grant funding and policy decisions.

Fernando Holguin, MD, is an asthma expert at CU who is leading the charge to find solutions to health problems affecting our most vulnerable populations. He is also training the next generation of leaders to address the health needs of our communities.
Donors’ gifts to CU are playing a major role in exploring these issues.

fields.title: Community-4
fields.description: Fernando Holguin, MD, talks to a female CU student

fields.label: Community 5
fields.title: Community 5
fields.bodyAudioText: "I'm sort of a big believer that when the health of a community improves, we all gain. So I think it's something we should all be invested in."
fields.bodyAudioCredit: Fernando Holguin, MD, a physician at UCHealth University of Colorado Hospital and director of the Colorado School of Public Health’s Latino Research and Policy Center

fields.title: Community-5
fields.description: Dr. Fernando Holguin sits at a conference table, his hand to forehead, listening intently about the preliminary study results.

fields.title: M-Community-5
fields.description: Dr. Fernando Holguin sits at a conference table, his hand to forehead, listening intently about the preliminary study results.

content.value: In 2018, Holguin and his peers in public health decided to see if research data could address what community organizations were worried about in Aurora: Were residents more at risk for sickness and disease because of their environment?

fields.title: Community-6
fields.description: A group of people - students, researchers and staff - stand in a conference room for a portrait after discussing early findings of a research project about asthma

fields.title: M-Community-6
fields.description: A group of people - students, researchers and staff - stand in a conference room for a portrait after discussing early findings of a research project about asthma

content.value: Holguin is partnering on a comprehensive and collaborative study with the Breathing Institute at Children’s Hospital Colorado and Colorado State University. Funded by Children’s Hospital Colorado, the study is part of a broader research and academic effort at CU to identify how health inequities are associated with social and economic disadvantages.

fields.title: Community -7-ChildrenExterior Still
fields.description: Cars park their cars and people walk into the the main entrance of Children's Hospital Colorado

content.value: The study explores asthma cases among families who live along the Colfax Corridor, where economic disadvantages are prevalent—for instance, 68 percent of families qualify for free or reduced-cost lunch, according to local schools.
The researchers have relied on local schools, businesses and community organizations like the Colfax Community Network (CCN) to help recruit families to participate in the study.
Here, members of the research team volunteer to pack bags of snacks and hygiene products before doing street outreach with CCN along the Colfax Corridor.

fields.title: Community-9
fields.description: A group of CU students and researchers stand at a table filled with boxes and help community organizers put chips, granola bars and toothbruches into plastic bags to deliver to the neighborhood residents.

fields.title: M-Community-9
fields.description: A group of CU students and researchers stand at a table filled with boxes and help community organizers put chips, granola bars and toothbruches into plastic bags to deliver to the neighborhood residents.

fields.label: Community 10
fields.title: Community 10
fields.bodyAudioText: "This is a project that came from the community. Because we are large institutions, because we have expertise in research, in medicine, we are able to tackle this problem from an angle and through a lens that our community partners would not have been able to."
fields.bodyAudioCredit: Kate Johnston, a community health manager at Children’s Hospital Colorado

fields.title: M-Community-10
fields.description: Kate Johnston has long curly hair and is standing with her colleagues.

fields.label: Community 11
fields.title: Community 11
fields.bodyAudioText: "To me, what's exciting about that is we are relying on our community partners to be successful. We could not do this project without them. They are gatekeepers; they are the knowledge holders."

fields.title: Community-11
fields.description: A group of CU students and researchers smile and stand in front of a van with community organizers before they begin their street outreach in Aurora, Colorado.

fields.title: M-Community-11
fields.description: A group of CU students and researchers smile and stand in front of a van with community organizers before they begin their street outreach in Aurora, Colorado.

fields.title: Community-12
fields.description: A female CU researcher walks along a sidewalk pulling a rolling bag of equipment behind her in front of a brick apartment building in Aurora, Colorado.

fields.title: M-Community-12
fields.description: A female CU researcher walks along a sidewalk pulling a rolling bag of equipment behind her in front of a brick apartment building in Aurora, Colorado.

content.value: Judith, who did not want her last name used, has lived in this garden-level apartment for eight years with her three children. She works as a house cleaner, cook and street vendor, and often she volunteers at her children’s schools and at a community clinic.
Judith and her family live within the Colfax Corridor.

fields.title: Community-13
fields.description: A mother listens in her living room to CU students and researchers as they explain the research project. A picture of the Virgin Mary hangs behind her on the wall.

fields.title: M-Community-13
fields.description: A mother listens in her living room to CU students and researchers as they explain the research project. A picture of the Virgin Mary hangs behind her on the wall.

content.value: The researchers collect data from households in many ways.

fields.title: Community-14
fields.description: A CU student and researcher enter the home of a study particpant and begin to ask her questions about her family's experience with episodes of asthma.

fields.title: Community-14-mobile
fields.description: A female CU researcher unpacks equipment and supplies from her rollaway suitcase to begin data collection.

content.value: They give families new vacuum cleaners equipped with special filters to collect dust samples from their floors.

fields.title: Community-15
fields.description: A teenage girl bends over to vacuum the carpet in her bedroom that she shares with her sister

fields.title: M-Community-15
fields.description: A teenage girl bends over to vacuum the carpet in her bedroom that she shares with her sister

content.value: They ask individuals to breathe into a device called a spirometer, which measures lung function.

fields.title: Community-16
fields.description: A teenage girl sits at a kitchen table and blows into a spirometer to measure her lung function. A female CU researcher sits across from her looking at the measurements on a computer.

fields.title: M-Community-16
fields.description: A teenage girl sits at a kitchen table and blows into a spirometer to measure her lung function. A female CU researcher sits across from her looking at the measurements on a computer.

content.value: And they install air quality sensors in residences, be it a motel, apartment or house, which measure indoor air every minute for a week.

fields.title: Community-17
fields.description: A CU student unwraps two air sensors to place them in the living room of a family; the mother stands by and a two children, a middle school age girl and elementary school age boy, by the couch look on.

fields.title: M-Community-17
fields.description: A CU student unwraps two air sensors to place them in the living room of a family; the mother stands by and a two children, a middle school age girl and elementary school age boy, by the couch look on.

fields.label: Community 18
fields.title: Community 18
fields.bodyAudioText: "We start to have these conversations about the social determinants of health. It's important because it's one of the key things, at least from a pulmonology perspective, from an asthma perspective, that we look at and say, ‘Hey, this is a huge trigger; what's going on for these families in these other areas as well?'"
fields.bodyAudioCredit: Arthur McFarlane, right, a population health analyst at Children’s Hospital Colorado

fields.title: Community-18
fields.description: Two men, a student and a community health expert, listen with their hands to their mouths during a meeting about the research project.

content.value: Individual measures like these can help identify patterns about a community’s public health and reveal clues about larger issues like housing, transportation, education, employment, health care and health care utilization.
Public health issues are complex and interdisciplinary, and strong partnerships are crucial to developing solutions.
Ellison Carter is an environmental engineer and assistant professor at Colorado State University. She joined the study earlier this year.

While the medical professionals at CU Anschutz and Children’s Hospital Colorado study data points about emergency room visits and lung function, Carter is helping them understand the air these families breathe in their homes.

fields.title: Community-20
fields.description: A physician listens to an environmental engineer speak during a group discussion about the study.

fields.title: Community-20-mobile
fields.description: A female environmental engineer speaks at a conference table where CU researchers and students sit to discuss a research project.

fields.label: Community 21
fields.title: Community 21
fields.bodyAudioText: "We’re hoping to learn some information that would give us insight into the kinds of interventions we could propose in a larger study to mitigate the asthma exacerbation that those families experience. I think the more we do that the more likely we’re able to effectively serve the Colorado population and maybe even create models that could be applicable in other parts of the United States."

fields.title: Community-21
fields.description: A female researcher explains to the table of attendees her findings about air particles.

fields.title: Community-21-mobile
fields.description: A female environmental engineer speaks at a conference table where CU researchers and students sit to discuss a research project.

content.value: Health inequities are differences in health that are closely linked with social, economic and environmental disadvantages. Disparities typically affect groups who have systematically experienced greater obstacles more so than the broader U.S. population, resulting in higher rates of disease and unnecessary costs that affect us all.
Improving health equity benefits the health of everyone.

Bolstered by a donor’s generosity in 2014, CU Anschutz offers a certificate that educates students about health issues specific to the Latino community. As part of the certificate program, CU students work on projects that address a public health issue and help develop interventions. The first CU students to earn the certificate graduated in 2019.
Diana Albor is a nurse at a health clinic in Colorado Springs. Last year, she received a CU scholarship and plans to graduate with a master’s in public health next fall.

fields.title: Community-24
fields.description: A female medical student holds her stethoscope around her neck

fields.title: M-Community-24
fields.description: A female medical student holds her stethoscope around her neck

content.value: Albor, seen here with her parents, grew up in Kansas City watching her father struggle to manage his diabetes around the obstacles to health care, like the cost of insurance, language barriers and cultural differences that sometimes exist between a patient and physician.
She enrolled in the Latino health certificate program last year.

fields.title: Community-25
fields.description: A female CU student stands side by side with her father and mother during a backyard barbecue.

fields.title: M-Community-25
fields.description: A female CU student stands side by side with her father and mother during a backyard barbecue.

fields.label: Community 26
fields.title: Community 26
fields.bodyAudioText: "I wanted to do something with my future where I knew I could give back to the community. That was something my parents instilled in me from a young age—giving back and helping those who need it."

fields.title: Community-26
fields.description: A CU medical student in her scrubs and with a stethoscope smiles and embraces her mother

fields.title: M-Community-26
fields.description: A CU medical student in her scrubs and with a stethoscope smiles and embraces her mother

content.value: Holguin hopes the certificate program will continue to expand career and research opportunities for CU students. Many of the students have decided to continue their work on public health issues, from vaping to maternal health to obesity, after graduation.

fields.title: Community-27
fields.description: A male physician speaks at a conference table where CU researchers and students sit to discuss a research project.

fields.title: M-Community-27
fields.description: A male physician speaks at a conference table where CU researchers and students sit to discuss a research project.

content.value: These hands-on learning experiences help prepare the next generation of leaders of public health, impacting the health of our communities for generations to come.

fields.title: Community-28
fields.description: A male CU student holds his pen in his hand to make a point during a group discussion about the asthma study as Fernando Holguin, MD, looks on.

fields.title: M-Community-28
fields.description: A male CU student holds his pen in his hand to make a point during a group discussion about the asthma study as Fernando Holguin, MD, looks on.

fields.socialMediaSuggestedDescription: CU is on a mission to better the health of our communities. See how our researchers and students are partnering with hospitals, schools and community groups to help one Colorado community breathe a little easier.

fields.label: Resilience
fields.title: We’re in this together

content.value: Empowering trauma survivors through hope

fields.title: Resilience thumbnail fix
fields.description: A graphic illustration collage of a pair of hands holding a fidget spinner with a man's back to you

fields.creditJumpText: This is where people can find a way forward.

content.value: After a roadside bomb blew up his U.S. Army truck on Hell’s Highway, an infamously dangerous road in Helmand province in Afghanistan, Mike was trapped amid the flames and twisted metal.

fields.title: Resilience-2
fields.description: Three US Army soldiers walk along a barren desert road in Afghanistan scanning the ground for IEDs

fields.label: Resilience 3
fields.bodyAudioText: "My door was jammed. I couldn't open my door. It was stuck from the blast. They were like, 'Hey, your truck's on fire. You need to get out. You need to get out.' Then that just kind of puts you into a panic."
fields.bodyAudioCredit: Mike, a U.S. Army veteran who asked that his last name not be used in this story

fields.label: Resilience 4
fields.bodyAudioText: "We had to get out. We were getting shot at. It was an ambush. We tried to get the fire extinguisher to put the fire out first. They're shooting at us while we are trying to, you know, because we don't want all of our stuff to burn...We're engaging in a fire fight and trying to put the fire out."

content.value: Fellow soldiers helped Mike, a squad leader, get out of the burning vehicle. The bomb had thrown him against the windshield knocking him unconscious. Shaken awake by a fellow soldier, Mike found his ears leaking fluid and his jaw locking.
He felt nauseated. He had a headache. He needed a cigarette.
Despite his injuries, Mike and his men immediately began to check the ground underneath them for more bombs.
The threat of death was all around Mike that day in 2016.
Mike received a Purple Heart and a Combat Infantryman Badge.

fields.title: Resilience - 6 - Purple heart
fields.description: A graphic illustration of a Purple Heart medal

fields.title: M-Community-6
fields.description: A graphic illustration of a Purple Heart medal

content.value: Mike served in the U.S. Army for nine years and 10 months with two deployments to Afghanistan.

His tools of survival were the instruments of war—guns, bullets, bombs, and on that terrible day, two Apache helicopters and their pilots who protected Mike and his squad from enemy machine guns for hours before they were rescued.

fields.title: Resilience-7
fields.description: A US veteran walks into the Lane Center to meet with his therapist.

fields.title: M-Resilience-7
fields.description: A US veteran walks into the Lane Center to meet with his therapist.

content.value: Mike is now fighting new enemies: post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and traumatic brain injury (TBI)—the unwelcome souvenirs of war often diagnosed in combat veterans. His tools of survival: sobriety, hearing aids, weekly counseling appointments, neurofeedback, yoga, rides on his Harley-Davidson motorcycle, the gym, and a fidget spinner that helps quiet his brain and busies his hands.

fields.title: Resilience-8
fields.description: A veteran holds a fidget spinner in his right palm, which he uses when he is feeling anxious.

fields.title: M-Resilience-8
fields.description: A veteran holds a fidget spinner in his right palm, which he uses when he is feeling anxious.

content.value: His comrades today: the University of Colorado Colorado Springs, with organizations that partner to help thousands of U.S. veterans not only survive but thrive, and generous donors who support CU to make sure no one is left behind.

fields.title: Resilience-9
fields.description: Mike, a US Army veteran, wears a goatee and moustache, a black sports cap and black T-shirt, while standing in the lobby of the Lane Center where he receives mental health care for trauma experienced in combat.

fields.title: M-Resilience-9
fields.description: Mike, a US Army veteran, wears a goatee and moustache, a black sports cap and black T-shirt, while standing in the lobby of the Lane Center where he receives mental health care for trauma experienced in combat.

content.value: Gifts totaling $5.2 million to UCCS established the Veterans Health and Trauma Clinic, located in the Lane Center for Academic Health Sciences, and later expanded the center’s work with TBI research.

The gifts also created a trauma track in the clinical psychology PhD program to serve the health needs of military veterans and other trauma survivors. So far, 12 PhD and five master’s students are enrolled.

fields.title: Resilience-10
fields.description: A beautiful blue sky with puffy white clouds is seen in the distance over the mountain range, with the Lane Center building entrance off to the right.

fields.title: M-Resilience-10
fields.description: A beautiful blue sky with puffy white clouds is seen in the distance over the mountain range, with the Lane Center building entrance off to the right.

content.value: Generous gifts from donors help UCCS partner with organizations to meet the significant demand for clinical care and mental health research for veterans in Colorado and beyond.
The need is especially significant in El Paso County, where 125,000 veterans call home.

fields.title: Resilience-11
fields.description: Four US Army soldiers and their commander stand at attention to the US flag on the University of Colorado Colorado Springs campus.

fields.title: M-Resilience-11
fields.description: Four US Army soldiers and their commander stand at attention to the US flag on the University of Colorado Colorado Springs campus.

content.value: Psychology Professor Charles “Chip” Benight has focused his career on serving those who are suffering.

fields.title: Resilience-12
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight walks toward you somberly looking off to the side.

fields.title: M-Resilience-12
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight walks toward you somberly looking off to the side.

fields.label: Resilience 13
fields.bodyAudioText:
"There’s such strong support for veterans here in the community. This was like seeing what can happen when a community wraps around an individual and helps them. 

For me, it was really trying to make a difference in trauma survivors' lives around how to get them back on their feet."

fields.title: Resilience-13
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight walks toward you smiling along a road with bluffs at sunrise.

fields.title: M-Resilience-13
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight walks toward you smiling along a road with bluffs at sunrise.

content.value: More than 80% of people will experience at least one traumatic event in their lifetime, according to research. Some people will experience PTSD, which can include flashbacks, avoidance, negative thoughts and moods, and hyperactivity that can significantly affect their daily lives.

Approximately 15% to 20% of returning veterans experience clinically significant post-traumatic stress, Benight says. His clinic’s approach focuses on resilience—the strengths which people can use to assist and empower them in their recovery—rather than viewing trauma survivors as sick and impaired.

Benight serves as director of the UCCS Trauma, Health, and Hazards Center, which houses the clinic. Since 2014, the clinic has treated 1,047 active military personnel and veterans and made more than 28,000 contacts with patients who have endured trauma.

fields.title: Resilience-15
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight walks down the stairs of the Lane Center on the University of Colorado Colorado Springs campus.

fields.label: Resilience 16
fields.bodyAudioText: "We're basically saving lives. It's taking people and giving them mental health care that they desperately need. I think they deserve that and that they're getting the right kind of care enables these individuals to become contributing citizens to the community again."

fields.title: Resilience-16
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight sits outside on the stairs smiling

fields.title: M-Resilience-16
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight sits outside on the stairs smiling

content.value: For example, the clinic provides evaluation services for El Paso County’s veteran trauma court, an alternative to incarceration for U.S. military veterans and active duty military who are in the legal system because of trauma-related issues. Thanks to treatment, close probation supervision and regular drug testing, this program helps reduce recidivism and increase public safety.

The clinic also partners with community organizations across the state and nation, like  Headstrong based in New York and Operation TBI Freedom of Craig’s Hospital in Colorado Springs. Both address veterans’ health needs, especially for those who served after 9/11.

Since 2012, Headstrong has provided free and confidential mental health treatment for post-9/11 veterans and their families in an effort to eradicate possible barriers like high costs, bureaucracy and stigma. In partnership with Weill Cornell Medicine, Headstrong uses individually tailored and comprehensive treatment programs for PTSD and related military trauma.

Headstrong works in 25 markets around the country, contracting with more than 100 psychotherapists. In Colorado, Headstrong supports 154 clients in trauma treatment—93 in Colorado Springs, 48 in Denver and 13 in Boulder—making the Centennial State its largest market.

fields.label: Resilience 20
fields.bodyAudioText: "We have just the best relationship with UCCS. They are great at what they do, and they allow us to provide the funding, the clients and the support necessary to create an experience for the veterans that I don't think they would have had otherwise. The synergy between Headstrong and UCCS is an example of a great partnership."

fields.title: Resilience-20
fields.description: Gerard Ilaria of Headstrong wears glasses and smiles

fields.title: M-Resilience-20
fields.description: Gerard Ilaria of Headstrong wears glasses and smiles

content.value: Twenty veterans a day die by suicide. They comprise 14% of all suicides, even though veterans only make up 8% of the U.S. population.
Mike contacted Headstrong after he medically retired from the U.S. Army in late 2018.
His war wounds, both hidden and visible, ended what Mike had hoped would be a long military career.

fields.title: Resilience-22
fields.description: Mike turns to his left with his right crossing his upper body as he talks during therapy.

fields.label: Resilience 23
fields.bodyAudioText: "It was hard, super hard for me to ask for help. I was embarrassed to ask for help. My mentality was I'm going to be a lifer in the Army and, you know, be someone big in the military, do something like that. It got cut short because of my injuries that happened in Afghanistan."

fields.title: Resilience-23
fields.description: A man's hands clasp tightly together, the arms heavily tattoed, as he sits in a chair

content.value: Within 48 hours of completing an online form, Mike was on the phone with a psychiatrist from Headstrong for an evaluation.
Ultimately, they connected Mike with Erin Fowler, a UCCS clinician at the Veterans Health and Trauma Clinic whose expertise is counseling combat veterans just like him.

fields.title: Resilience-24
fields.description: A heavily tattooed arm of a man is extended as the veteran tells how he survived combat in front of a bookcase filled with self-help books, a stuffed animal and other trinkets.

fields.title: M-Resilience-24
fields.description: A heavily tattooed arm of a man is extended as the veteran tells how he survived combat in front of a bookcase filled with self-help books, a stuffed animal and other trinkets.

content.value: After months of dealing with suicidal ideation, rage, and alcohol and substance abuse issues, Mike had a lifeline. Mike has lost fellow soldiers he served with to suicide.
This year he almost joined them.

fields.title: Resilience-25
fields.description: A female mental health clinican leans over in her chair to listen to a veteran sitting across from her during a therapy session. A bookcase filled with books and plants is against the wall.

fields.title: M-Resilience-25
fields.description: A female mental health clinican leans over in her chair to listen to a veteran sitting across from her during a therapy session. A bookcase filled with books and plants is against the wall.

content.value: Partnerships like the one between Headstrong and UCCS are important because the availability and urgency needed for mental health services, especially for veterans, cannot always meet demand.
Those who need help can sometimes face restrictions, privacy issues, stigma, high costs or long waitlists for mental health services from traditional sources.

fields.title: Resilience-26
fields.description: Students, many of whom include active military and veterans, walk across the UCCS campus in Colorado Springs.

fields.title: M-Resilience-26
fields.description: Students, many of whom include active military and veterans, walk across the UCCS campus in Colorado Springs.

content.value: Mike is proud that he served his country. He is embracing his identity as a veteran and mastering the tools given to him by the Veterans Health and Trauma Clinic at UCCS.

He wants to be a better father to his two kids. He talks now with friends and family about therapy. He wants to break down the stigma around mental health and encourage other veterans to seek help if they need it.

fields.title: Resilience-27
fields.description: Mike, a US veteran, sits in a chair with his hands folded together as he tells his stories of combat

fields.title: M-Resilience-27
fields.description: Mike, a US veteran, sits in a chair with his hands folded together as he tells his stories of combat

fields.label: Resilience 28
fields.bodyAudioText: "It feels good...to know that there's people out there that care about us. The peace I get is maybe one [veteran] might read this and be like, ‘You know what, let's go try therapy.’ That to me is worth it."

fields.title: Resilience-28
fields.description: A man's hands clasp together

fields.label: Resilience 29

content.value: In 2020, Benight is launching a new National Resilience Institute at UCCS to help survivors of all types of trauma like car crashes, sexual assault, natural disasters, mass shootings and, of course, combat.
Here, survivors can seek a strength-based approach to trauma care and recovery through hope and healing, not just managing their symptoms.

fields.title: Resilience-29
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight stands facing the sunrise in Garden of the Gods park in Colorado Springs

fields.title: M-Resilience-29
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight stands facing the sunrise in Garden of the Gods park in Colorado Springs

fields.label: Resilience 30
fields.bodyAudioText: "We need to think about people more holistically and help them generate a sense of recovery through their own empowerment. What we really focus on is to identify the strengths that individuals have in the aftermath of a trauma, and then help them with processing and moving forward after they've gone through probably one of the most horrific things they've ever gone through. We're a place where people can find a way forward, really."

fields.title: Resilience-30
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight stands in the Garden of the Gods park in Colorado Springs facing east

fields.title: M-Resilience-30
fields.description: Professor Charles "Chip" Benight stands in the Garden of the Gods park in Colorado Springs facing east.

fields.socialMediaSuggestedDescription: Did you know 125,000 veterans call the Pikes Peak region home? Learn how Professor Charles "Chip" Benight is helping military veterans suffering the invisible wounds of war through an innovative approach to research and clinical care at UCCS.
